content:
Click the 3-bar menu icon in the upper right, New Account, Email, enter your credentials, then click Manual config. and enter these settings:

incoming POP server: mail.zianet.com, port 110, security = none, authentication = password, transmitted insecurely, User Name = part of address before @

outgoing SMTP server: mail.zianet.com, port 587, security = none, authentication = password, transmitted insecurely, User Name = part of address before @

https://w3.zianet.com/mozilla-thunderbird-e-mail-setup.html

content:
1. Over half of your space usage is in the "All Mail" folder, whose messages don't actually get deleted unless you manually go into that folder and delete them. (I find that deleting them using gmail web is most effective)

2. You don't need to be subscribed to the "All Mail" folder in Thunderbird, which will save you considerable disk space.

3. On the off chance that you have lingering files from old compacts, look for files with nstmp in the file name.
creator: wsmwk

content:
Thanks for reply Wayne.

1/. Don't quite understande what your saying re "All Mail" folder. I assumed this was basically the "Inbox" folder, and that if I deleted all the mails in the "All Mail" folder they would disappear from Inbox also?

2/. Also don't understand what you mean by 'subscribed' to All Mail folder - so far as I remember this was the default folder setup when first installed TB
creator: monsoonhoy

content:
Peter Hoy said
Thanks for reply Wayne. 1/. Don't quite understande what your saying re "All Mail" folder. I assumed this was basically the "Inbox" folder, and that if I deleted all the mails in the "All Mail" folder they would disappear from Inbox also?

gmail is an odd beast - if you delete a message from all your folders including Trash, it still exists in All Mail. Also, because of how gmail labels are map to imap folders, every message exists in at least two imap folders.

Peter Hoy said
2/. Also don't understand what you mean by 'subscribed' to All Mail folder - so far as I remember this was the default folder setup when first installed TB

Yes, All Mail folder is presented by default. But it isn't needed in Thunderbird for proper operation. To remove it from Thunderbird:

  • Unsubscribe - Right click on the gmail account and click "Subscribe", find the All Mail folder, uncheck it, then click OK. To free up the space on your disk, you then need to go to the directory
  • Free the space - Right click on the gmail account and pick Settings, then Server Settings, then at "Local Directory" click the Browse button. Under "[Gmail].sbd you should see two files All Mail and All Mail.msf. Shut down Thunderbird. Delete the two files.

Some background at https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-gmail, although not everything is well described there.

content:
Peter Hoy said
Thanks once again Wayne - unsubscribed the "All Mail" folder and retrieved a big whack of disk space (didn't need to do the second step as it had already deleted the .sbd files).

But you had to delete All Mail and All Mail.msf manually, correct?

Peter Hoy said
If I could just follow up on a few related concerns :- 1/. How is it that my gmail folder could get to 120 odd GB? My understanding is that Google only allow 15gb of 'free' storage and then won't allow any future download? Is it possible that 15,000 emails (nearly all text - no attachments) would be 120GB??

In the case of gmail, that amount you see on the server is not what you will see on your PC, as you have discovered - All Mail was approximately half of that, and is now gone.

The question now is, how big is Inbox on your PC? Right+click on the folder in Thunderbird and pick properties.


Peter Hoy said
2/. I'm still unable to compact folders - now getting the attached error message.

This is a known bug.

Peter Hoy said
In the lower left of application, is the message "Downloading message xxx of xx,xxx in Inbox" and it slowly counts away.

This is a potential symptom when the All Mail folder is subscribed on the PC.

content: A tip: when posting questions, it always helps to share some details. Now that I know you use gmail, I can advise that if you UNTICK saving the message in sent folder, that gmail does it anyway. That implies to me that you have it set to store the message, and that is causing you to have two copies. You can verify this by unticking the Sent folder setting, send a message, and then check the sent folder and the message should be there. See, you learned something today. :) Enjoy.
creator: davidsk

content: Gmail automatically copies sent messages to Sent Mail, so uncheck 'Place a copy in' in Account Settings, Copies & Folders. Unsubscribe Sent by right-clicking the account in the Folder Pane, Subscribe... In the same Subscribe window, unsubscribe the Drafts folder that appears near the top of the list and subscribe the Drafts folder under [Gmail], lower down. Set drafts to be saved in [Gmail]/Drafts in Copies & Folders, or Drafts on Local Folders if you don't need to access drafts on multiple devices.

content:
You must provide information on the current situation.

You say you cannot receive nor send any emails. We need to check you are using the correct server settings. We need to check nothing is being blocked. We need to know more about your computer and the set up.

You need to do this on computer first then answer the questions: Check Firewall. Access the Firewall, it might be controlled by the default on computer or controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed. Thunderbird must be set up as an allowed program. Please confirm you have set up the Thunderbird program as allowed.

VPN Please check your computer to see if a VPN has been enabled. Some Anti-Virus products provide VPN and it might have been enabled automatically. You need to disable / switch off the VPN because servers think you are a hacker as it hides your IP address. Confirm you have switched off VPN.

Provide information on the following: 1. What Operating System are you using? eg: Windows 10, MAC, Linux ?

2. What version of Thunderbird are you using? You can find that information under 'Help' >'About Thunderbird'

3. Where did you get the Thunderbird download/program ? Did you get it from the official website at this link: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

Or did you get from 'Windows App Store' or Flatpak or Snap ?

4. What server settings are you currently using ?

  • That means in 'Account Settings'
  • select name of the account in left pane
  • Look bottom right and click on 'Edit SMTP_Server' button
  • create a screenshot of the window and upload an image to this forum question
  • Then select 'Server Settings' for the account in left pane
  • Create a screen shot of the window and upload an image to this forum question.

5. In Thunderbird, 'Help' > 'Troubleshooting Information'

  • Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' section
  • Copy all the data in that section and paste it into this forum question.

6. When you start Thunderbird, do you see all your mail accounts and folders in the Folder Pane?

  • Create ascreenshot of what you see when you start up Thunderbird and upload an image to this forum question.

How to create a screen shot:

  • Use the 'Prt Scr' key on keyboard to capture an image of what you see on monitor/screen.
  • Open a simple Paint program
  • Use 'Ctrl+V' to Paste screen shot into Paint.
  • Save as a JPG image to desktop
  • Finally upload JPG image to this forum question - below the Reply box is a 'Add images' - clickon the 'Browse button, locate image on desktop and clickon 'Open'.

content:
Also make sure you do not use a VPN.

Turn off your anti-virus software during the authentication attempt.

In general it is recommended to create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-do-i-find-my-profile

Are you running some sort of software like a web server, which is blocking TCP port 80 on localhost? This can also be anti-virus/security software blocking that port.

Start Thunderbird in troubleshooting mode. Does the problem go away?

content:
Here's a simple way, done with windows file explorer - click account settings - click to Local Folders pane - note the file location in the Local Directory line at bottom - exit thunderbird - IMPORTANT - in windows file explorer, copy (not move) that exact folder to the external drive - now, restart thunderbird - locate the local folders pane as before - click the local folders dropdown on bottom line and set to the new location. thunderbird will likely close and restart - check that all is well and that the Local Folders pane points as desired - you can now delete the Local Folders folder in the C drive.

REMEMBER: When you do backups or transfer to new PC,you need to stay aware that part of your account is not in the profile.
creator: davidsk

content:
Go to Outgoing Server (SMTP) in the account settings and make sure that all instances of SMTP servers for that gmail server name have an authentication method of oauth. Oauth pops up requests for re-authentication in web page sized windows, little dialogs asking for a password are a clear indicator of years out of date authentication settings.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20

content:
Is your computer managed by your employer, school, or another organization?

Check the update debug log and other update files:

  1. Settings > General > Config Editor (https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/config-editor)
  2. Paste in app.update.log and set it to true
  3. Open the Console either with the hotkey Control+Shift+J (Command+Shift+J on macOS), or via Hamburger Menu->Tools->Developer Tools->Console
  4. Near the top, in the text field "Filter Output", enter AUS: to select just messages related to updates. Check that Logs is highlighted at "Errors Warnings Logs".
  5. In Settings' search field type or paste "updates", then click on the button "Update to xxx" or "Check for Updates"
  6. Once the update check has completed, copy the messages out of the Console and attach them here.
  7. In same area of Settings click the button "Show Update History" and screen shot it
  8. If the update process began and is being investigated, do Help > Troubleshooting Information to find "Update Folder", click "Open Folder" or "Show in Finder" and expand that directory to find last-update.log, last-update.log and backup-update.log and attach

content:
Well now everything is messed up and I don't know if I'm coming or going!. Emails are now going to my Comcast email account, even though I've used Thunderbird as a 3rd party email for years. Certain things go to the Comcast account....and other emails go to the TB account. I have absolutely NO idea what I did, or what might have happened to cause this! I've tried deleting the account and bring it back up...and even though the password is correct, along with all the other information, it won't accept it saying "either the password and address is wrong." And they are correct! So at this point I have absolutely no idea what to do. It seems so much more complicated than what it should be.....any help at all would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you,

Michael....
creator: MKS1

content:
Comcast uses the Xfinity server.

Logon to your comcast webmail account via a browser (eg: Firefox) to see emails on server. All your emails will be displayed. Please confirm you can access webmail account as this confirms the password is ok.

Now check the following to make sure it allows Thunderbird to access the server. I've also added an image below as a guide. https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/third-party-email-access

In Thunderbird for IMAP comcast account: These are the server settings required. IMAP

  • Incoming Mail Server Name: imap.comcast.net
  • Port Number: 993
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username = full comcast email address

SMTP

  • Outgoing Mail Server Name: smtp.comcast.net
  • Port Number: 587
  • Connection Security: STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username = full comcast email address

Additional Checks: Firewall: Access Firewall - this may the default that came with computer or controlled by an Anti-virus product you installed. Thunderbird needs to be set up as an allowed program so that nothing blocks it's access.

VPN Check to see if you have a VPN enabled. Many Anti-virus products now provide a VPN and in some cases it can be auto enabled. So please check this. If you have a VPN then switch it off because servers do not like VPN as it hides your real IP that means servers think you may be a hacker so they block access. Alternatively, if you really want o use the VPN then you need to set up split tunnelling and set up Thunderbird to use it, so it does not use the VPN.

IMAP accounts - folders need to be subscribed to be seen. Right click on imap account name and select 'Subscribe' choose folders on server and click on 'Subscribe' then click on OK

Imap accounts can only display whatever is on server.

REgarding the emails going to 'Junk' - which is called 'Spam' by Xfinity. Emails in the Junk folder can be put there by the server and/or Thunderbird. If emails in Junk folder have a red flame icon then Thunderbird put them in Junk. If they have a grey flame icon then they were put there by the server.

You can set your Junk Settings in:

  • 'Account Settings' > 'Junk Settings' for the comcast account.

It may help to post an image showing what you have got set up so we can advise. But you should:

  • enable adaptive junk controls
  • choose address books to act as a whitelist

Destination and Retention

  • select 'Move new junk messages to'
  • Select 'Other' and choose the server default spam folder on account.

In webmail account accessed via a browser you can set up server filtering for junk/spam. See info at this link: https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/spam-filters-and-email-blocking-new-experience

As for junk/spam folder suddenly not having emails - The server will auto empty the Spam folder after emails have been in it for 7 days. Then when you select to see Junk/Spam folder it synchronises with server folder and will get updated to display the server contents. So emails will disappear if removed by server.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Thank you so much for your reply Toad-Hall. I followed through with all of your suggestions, and even unchecking the Third Party box in Comcast email. Although it was previously checked and I had no issues. The "Port" setting was previously at "465" I believe, and the incoming was set at "993." I have added a screenshot of what I'm continually getting when doing the configuration manually. Now....I'm getting important emails coming only to the Comcast account, and not to my TB account which is distressing because they're pretty important emails. I also turned of my VPN which I have through Malwarebytes. The part about "right clicking" on the imap I didn't understand. I should also add that everything coming into TB is showing as junk in my inbox and I'm having to uncheck the yellow warning banner for each non-junk email coming in. I've never had an issue like this with TB, and I've been using this email client for a number of years now. Totally frustrating as you can imagine. Hopefully the screenshot might help a little, and I'll await your reply on this matter. Again...thank you so much for your help!

creator: MKS1

content:
That image does not look like an Imap account because I would have expected to see more default folders. I would also expect to see 'Spam' not 'Junk'. I would also expect you to be subscribing to see folders and store email on server. However, you also seem to be using 'Local Folders' to store emails. So let's be clear - you say "I fear losing all of my sub-folders in my email account" - you do not have any subfolders in your comcast mail account - all your folders are in the 'Local Folders' default account.

Let's check something.

  • In 'Account SEttings'
  • In left pane
  • Select 'Server Settings' for the comcast mail account.
  • Look top right for 'Server Type' - What does it say ? 'Pop Mail Server' or 'Imap Mail Server'
  • Please post an image which displays that entire Account SEttings window as it would help.
  • In 'Account Settings'
  • Select 'Junk Settings' for the comcast account.
  • Post an image showing what you have got set up so we can advise.


You say " I think it may NOT be working' It obviously is working because you have posted an image which shows you received an email from this support Forum. In fact it shows you have been receiving emails into the comcast Inbox with no problems. OK you have some junk mail flagged as junk by Thunderbird, but it seems you have not set up your Junk Settings hence why you see junk mail in the Inbox.

Please post the images of your Account Settings > 'Server Settings' and 'Junk Settings'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:

The local folders can be retrieved either from my external hard drive, or another source so I shouldn't place too much emphasis on the issue.

I figure like before, once I remove the TB account the system should automatically decide what it should do and figure in the correct incoming and outgoing servers based on the Comcast servers. I'm going to go ahead and try that now. And then I'd like to get back to you if possible, and update you on what's going on. You've been a tremendous help so far, and I'd like to keep you advised. So here goes nuttin'! I'll let you know.

content: Okay Toad-Hall.....I removed the account. I then went back on as though it was new account and had TB set it up. For some reason it was not taking my password, so I created a new password and once that was done TB recognized everything and reloaded all of my missing emails. Also, the Junk file and folder is working as it should so it seems that issue is also resolved. Now....I also went back to the Comcast email account to make sure everything was lining up correctly, and it seems as though it is. So at this point I would say the issue is resolved and corrected. Hopefully! Again, I thank you for your help. It's unfortunate I can't contact you directly through TB if and when in the future I have difficulties. And I'm sure I will!
